unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, as many of you know, I'm a first-time parent to a beautiful baby girl, Aisha. And let me tell you, navigating the world of pediatrics has been quite the adventure! I thought I'd share some of my experiences, especially since I've been doing a ton of research.
normalised: Hey everyone! So, as many of you know, I'm a first-time parent to a beautiful baby girl, Aisha. And let me tell you, navigating the world of pediatrics has been quite the adventure! I thought I'd share some of my experiences, especially since I've been doing a ton of research.

unnormalised: Firstly, finding a good pediatrician in Mumbai was a top priority. We finally settled on Dr. Sharma at Lilavati Hospital. She came highly recommended and has been amazing so far. My friend Meera suggested her – thanks, Meera!
normalised: Firstly, finding a good pediatrician in Mumbai was a top priority. We finally settled on Doctor Sharma at Lilavati Hospital. She came highly recommended and has been amazing so far. My friend Meera suggested her – thanks, Meera!

unnormalised: One of the first things Dr. Sharma advised was vaccinations. We’re following the Indian Academy of Pediatrics schedule, which meant Aisha received her BCG vaccine shortly after birth. Now, we're prepping for the 6-week vaccines, which includes DTaP, Polio, and Hib. Honestly, I was a little nervous about the side effects, but Dr. Sharma reassured us that they're usually mild – maybe a slight fever and some fussiness.
normalised: One of the first things Doctor Sharma advised was vaccinations. We’re following the Indian Academy of Pediatrics schedule, which meant Aisha received her B-C-G vaccine shortly after birth. Now, we're prepping for the six-week vaccines, which includes D-T-a-P, Polio, and H-i-b. Honestly, I was a little nervous about the side effects, but Doctor Sharma reassured us that they're usually mild – maybe a slight fever and some fussiness.

unnormalised: Then there's the feeding schedule. At first, I was super stressed about whether Aisha was getting enough breast milk. I was constantly googling things like "is 8 feeds a day enough?" and obsessing over her weight gain. Dr. Sharma calmed my nerves by explaining that as long as she’s gaining weight steadily (around 150-200 grams per week), and producing 6-8 wet diapers a day, she’s doing fine.
normalised: Then there's the feeding schedule. At first, I was super stressed about whether Aisha was getting enough breast milk. I was constantly googling things like "is eight feeds a day enough?" and obsessing over her weight gain. Doctor Sharma calmed my nerves by explaining that as long as she’s gaining weight steadily (around one hundred and fifty to two hundred grams per week), and producing six to eight wet diapers a day, she’s doing fine.

unnormalised: We also had a minor scare when Aisha developed a rash on her tummy. Of course, I immediately jumped to worst-case scenarios, thinking it was some rare pediatric disease. But Dr. Sharma examined her and said it was just a mild case of eczema, likely triggered by a new laundry detergent. She prescribed a gentle emollient cream and the rash cleared up within a few days. Phew!

But Doctor Sharma examined her and said it was just a mild case of eczema, likely triggered by a new laundry detergent. She prescribed a gentle emollient cream and the rash cleared up within a few days. Phew!

unnormalised: Sleep, or rather the lack of it, is another big topic. Everyone told me that newborns sleep all the time, but Aisha seems to have missed that memo! She sleeps in short bursts, mostly during the day, and is wide awake at night. I’ve been trying all sorts of sleep training techniques, but nothing seems to work consistently. Anyone have tips for dealing with a baby who is up at 2 AM for a chai party?

unnormalised: On a slightly different note, I've also been researching developmental milestones. According to the charts, Aisha should be able to hold her head up for a short period by 2 months. She's almost there! It's so fascinating to watch her grow and learn new things every day.

unnormalised: Another thing I realized is the importance of having a good support system. My husband, Rohan, has been incredibly helpful with everything. And my mom has been a lifesaver, especially when I need a break. Seriously, new parents, don't be afraid to ask for help!

unnormalised: So, that's a little glimpse into my journey through pediatrics. It’s definitely been a rollercoaster, but I wouldn’t trade it for anything. Motherhood is tough, but seeing Aisha smile makes it all worthwhile.
